prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Regletil and Chatboard

'Twas satword, and the shifty bards
Did gyve and hew like fomblight fey.
All bimsy were the hambles, and the twards
Beware the Reglet, my seaguy!

Beware the Furnitil, and shun
Our hanfrails' wary, prinkled haunt.
So weirdly when the vextface sun
Pale gleams upon the marquint.

One two! One two! And through and through
The vorpaled blade went snicker-snack!
To wonkled groans of chatboards blue,
Beside the bangel's slackered track.

"And hast thou slain the Reglet? Come
With snicksnifed blade to claim thy prise."
'Twas brillig, and the shifty bards
Did gyve and hew like fomblight fey.
label: low

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Helical Scry
In the movement’s blued screw
Where gears gnarl and angles accrue
A new firmament did appear
With crystalline motions to steer

All mimsy were the mechanical gears
Churning time in tangling snares
Till seven saphire screws, all frabjous
Aligned flux and flexion flawless

"Grab thy motional gyre!" cried the fyre
"Whirlers implore this unending pyre!
For the movement, askew, ran a blue screw
To the nether-hoard, seeking one clue"

Three times ten and three fathoms per turn
The seeker rotated and did churn
Until, with a zoundling zark and zing
He found the path for rewings to sing

With a frabjulous wrench and a snicker-snack
The helix was conjured from the black
A shining new thread for the world to ensure
Of time's intertwined, helical lure
label: low

<C1_think>Title is present before the first stanza: "The Helical Scry".</C1_think>
<C2_think>Counting stanzas: 6 stanzas total, all quatrains (4 lines each), stanza count between 5 and 8, all quatrains confirmed.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Meter alternation: Checking line lengths within stanzas for alternating longer/shorter lines; alternation is inconsistent and less than 60% stanzas meet >2 content-word difference or clear longer/shorter pattern; borderline but insufficient.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme (2,4) per stanza: Some stanzas have clear end-rhyme on lines 2 and 4 (e.g. 'accrue'/'steer' does not rhyme; 'snares'/'flawless' no; mixed; only about 2 of 6 stanzas have decent rhyme on lines 2 and 4; also AABB pattern is present in some stanzas, lacking rhyme variety.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Ring composition: Final stanza does not echo the opening stanza with ≥2 repeated content words or a refrain; differs substantially with no clear refrain or repeated phrases from first stanza.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Warning/admonition present? No stanza gives clear admonition or caution to protagonist analogous to 'Beware the Jabberwock'.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation/armament: No explicit preparation before the encounter is evident (e.g. no tool given or waiting/resolve described before a direct confrontation).</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter/confrontation: Some hint of pursuit and action ("seeker rotated and did churn", "found the path for rewings to sing"), but no clear adversary or monster encountered; unclear if there is a direct confrontation.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Slaying/decisive action: The "snicker-snack" line suggests decisive action in stanza 6; the helix conjured from black implies resolution.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return/celebration: No identifiable return or joyous celebration stanza is present; ending is descriptive/metaphorical rather than celebratory.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Distinct invented coinages: Terms like "blued screw", "frabjous", "zoundling", "zark", "rewings", "snicker-snack" (canonical), "saphire" (spelling variant?), "frabjulous", "helix", "fyre", "motional gyre" (gyre is canonical), "nether-hoard"—counting at least 7-8 coinages including possibly reused canonical; reasonably meets threshold.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Coinage spread: Not every stanza contains at least one distinct coinage; e.g., first stanza has mostly English words except "movement's blued screw" (uncertain token), some stanzas have none.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Creature naming: No named non-canonical creature or entity central to action; "screws," "helix," "seeker" not creature names.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia: "snicker-snack" is canonical onomatopoeia; "zoundling zark and zing" possibly onomatopoeic bursts; at least 2 onomatopoeic bursts present.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance: Some alliteration present in few lines (e.g., "flux and flexion flawless", "seeker rotated and did churn" less so); at least 2 stanzas show clear alliteration beyond incidental; yes.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Canonical arc order: Warning absent, preparation unclear, encounter vague, decisive action present, no clear return/celebration; arc order not fully canonical or orderly.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No verbatim lines from canonical poem present.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Limit on canonical tokens: "snicker-snack", "gyre" are canonical; "frabjous" is close but standard? "snicker-snack" only once; canonical tokens ≤8, yes.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable tightness: Longer lines roughly 8–9 syllables and shorter lines ~5–7 syllables partially met but inconsistent; some lines notably shorter or longer; borderline but not consistent across all stanzas.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety: Limited rhyme variety; some repetition and slant rhyme, but less than ideal; some rhyme pairs reused; no heavy exact reuse of end-words >2 times, so yes.</C20_think>
<C21_think>Lexical repetition guard: No content word is overused (>5 times or >8%); vocabulary well varied.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinage variety: Coinages have distinct roots (zoundling, fyre, rewings, saphire) and no dominant suffix >50%; good variety.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Topic adherence: Poem is on an abstract, mechanical/clockwork theme not on Jabberwock or a monster fight; no explicit Jabberwock or analogous creature; topic adherence to Jabberwocky style is partial due to form and coinage, but topic of Jabberwock is not clearly addressed.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext: No strong coherent implied layer or motif beyond surface of mechanical movement and invention; subtext is weak or vague.</C24_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
*Gythwindling Skyward*

The Lectern rook doth gythwind home
Above the stubbles, quivering,
Where mischievous Woggles chorbled, roamed
And fibril-swam, awhirling.

'Beware the mathbox, my son!
The frumious mop-frobbles bite,
Beware the clack-crickets,
and shun
The villainous phauble-white!'

The boy he fossicked through the field
His gibbet-tusked snorke-spear in hand,
And as the rooks returned, he wielded
The callway-sling with doughty stand.

One two! One two! And through and through!
He snicked each squessel-wozzle fine,
Defang'd the trigons, and did cut
The vaporous flurches from behind.

He camfisqued home, through stubble tall
His gibbet-tusked snorke-spear unclean,
And as he pranked and preening-turned,
He rested on the choppeen green.

'Has thou dispatched all my foe,
O valiant, Lectern-limbered son?
Come to my arms, my mathbox-slaying,
O frabjous Lectern-spark that's won!'
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line present before the first stanza: "Gythwindling Skyward" clearly given as a title.</C1_think>
<C2_think>Stanzas count: poem has 6 stanzas; line counts per stanza: 1st stanza=4 lines, 2nd=4, 3rd=4, 4th=4, 5th=4, 6th=4; all stanzas are quatrains; total stanza count is 6, which is between 5 and 8 inclusive.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Meter: Checking if in ≥60% stanzas lines alternate longer/shorter with ≥2 content-word difference. The line lengths are close but vary; first stanza lines are 8/5/7/6 syllables approx, similar to Jabberwocky’s pattern; several stanzas show alternation with content word differences >=2; at least 4 of 6 stanzas show alternating line lengths and stress pattern consistent with ballad meter.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme: Lines 2 and 4 rhyme (or slant rhyme) in most stanzas: e.g., "quivering" / "awhirling" (slant), "bite" / "white" (end rhyme), "hand" / "stand" (perfect rhyme), "through" / "behind" (less perfect rhyme), "unclean" / "green" (perfect rhyme), "son" / "won" (perfect rhyme). AABB rhyme is avoided; no clear AABB dominance. ≥60% stanzas meet (2,4) rhyme.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Ring composition: Last stanza echoes opening themes or repeated content? The final stanza has some refrains like "Come to my arms," "O frabjous," echoing Jabberwocky style but no clear repeated content words/phrases from the first stanza or "Gythwindling Skyward" repeated. So no clear ring echo with repeated content words/phrases from start to finish.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Warning/admonition present: Second stanza is a clear warning "’Beware the mathbox, my son!" analogous to Jabberwocky’s admonition; yes.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation/armament: Third stanza shows boy preparing with "His gibbet-tusked snorke-spear in hand," implying preparation before confrontation.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter/confrontation: Fourth stanza depicts a clear encounter/confrontation: "One two! One two! And through and through! He snicked each squessel-wozzle fine," showing a clash between protagonist and adversary.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Slaying/decisive action: Same stanza describes a decisive action "He snicked...," the weapon striking and defeating foes ("Defang'd the trigons"); so yes.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return/celebration: Fifth stanza shows return home ("He camfisqued home") but is muted and doesn't clearly celebrate; sixth stanza has a celebratory tone with "O valiant... Come to my arms... O frabjous... that’s won," so return and celebration appear present.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Coinage count: Count creative invented words excluding canonical Lewis Carroll tokens. Words like gythwind, chorbled, fibril-swam, mathbox, mop-frobbles, clack-crickets, phauble-white, fossicked, gibbet-tusked, snorke-spear, callway-sling, snicked, squessel-wozzle, defang'd, trigons, vaporous flurches, camfisqued, pranked, choppeen, mathbox-slaying, Lectern-limbered, Lectern-spark — well over 8 distinct invented coinages present.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Coinage spread: Almost every stanza has at least one coined word or phrase; no stanza purely standard English.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Creature naming: A creature/entity is named: "mathbox" is the adversary and central to action; also "Lectern rook" introduces a named entity but "mathbox" is the main confronted foe distinct from canonical Jabberwock.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia: Poem has "One two! One two! And through and through! He snicked each squessel-wozzle fine," "snicked" may count as onomatopoeic burst; but no multiple clear onomatopoeic bursts like "snicker-snack" or "burbled." Only one clear onomatopoeia - "snicked." Need ≥2, so no.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance: Several stanzas show internal alliteration: "fossicked... field," "gibbet-tusked snorke-spear," "pranked and preening-turned," "mischievous Woggles chorbled," so yes, ≥2 stanzas show clear alliteration/consonance.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order: The poem follows canonical arc order: warning (stanza 2), preparation (3), encounter (4), decisive action (4), return (5), celebration (6). So yes.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No verbatim lines: No lines exactly copied from canonical Jabberwocky poem; all new lines, no verbatim matches.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical token budget: Uses a few canonical tokens ("frumious" and "O frabjous"), but under 8 distinct canonical tokens; majority are new coinages.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable tightness: Lines mostly within 5-9 syllables for shorter/longer; some lines slightly longer but mostly aligned with Jabberwocky’s ~8/6 pattern; every quatrain stanza respects this.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety: (2,4) end rhymes mostly varied; repeats minimal; no end word reused >2 times excluding ring echo. So yes.</C20_think>
<C21_think>Lexical repetition guard: No single content word is overly repeated (>5 times). Coinages are numerous and spread out; no overused standard English content word found.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinage variety: Multiple roots appear in coined words; no single suffix accounts for more than half of coinages. Good variety.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Topic adherence: Poem clearly addresses a Jabberwocky-like mythical battle with a non-canonical creature; fits model poem style replacing Jabberwock with mathbox; topic adhered to.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext: Implied coming-of-age, bravery, and triumph archetype consistent throughout; a coherent undertone across poem present.</C24_think>
</think>
